replies.context: You probably know well that this isn't an isolated incident.  People throughout the state lose their animals to gators all of the time since they take their dogs, etc. down to ponds, rivers, lakes, etc.  There should be a law against this kind of stupidity and, moreover, its animal cruelty.  There was a sad story a couple of years ago concerning a young vet that lost his dog to a gator.  He was upset with himself since he definitely knew better (walked him around a lake frequented by Gators);  He was so consumed with sadness, self-loathing that he killed himself over it within 24 hours of losing his dog - obviously his reaction to the loss of his pet was definitely extreme but pet owner's can easily relate to how he felt - he also had PTSD but his dog meant everything to him.  Its a horrible story since this guy was an honorable veteran and he had everything going for him, very upsetting all around.  It should be a cautionary tale for people that live in gator territory.

context: I live in Florida and every year there are some incidents involving an alligator.  Natives of the state know better than to get around ponds with alligators.  Never feed alligators. That's a big no no.  We don't live on the beach, either, because of hurricanes and spring breakers.  When I was growing up in South Florida, my cousins and I would swim at Telegraph Creek.  Without saying, we all kept watch for alligators.  To this day, the habit of watching out for alligators is just something that is part of living here.

replies.context: If I can't live on the coast of Florida I would not live there if you paid me.  My mom lived on one of the Gulf Coast barrier Islands for 30+ years and it was beautiful.  The interior, not so much for sure.
Agreed.

That‚Äôs a silly judgement. I grew up in the interior of Central Florida & right on a lake. it was a beautiful, lush, peaceful area with huge live oaks, cypress trees and tons of birds and wildlife. And, yes, yes we swam in the lake throughout  my youth, but always with supervision. And, no, we did not allow our pets to go into the water.

I respectfully disagree. The woods in Old Florida, the swamps, the little rivers running all over the state, the lakes and ponds, are just gorgeous when not abused by or full of wasteful, littering humans.

If you think that living cramped, side-by-side on an island (just like city living, except for the VERY EXPENSIVE beach views) that's full of transient people trampling all over your property and despoiling your view, more power to ya'. 

Beauty is in the eye of the beholder, but I can show you plenty of beauty in the interior of Florida. I'll take an occasional jaunt to the beach...but I prefer the interior of the state, personally. WAY less crowded. WAY quieter than the coast.
My cousin lives on telegraph Creek and the area around there is growing quickly but still a beautiful place.  I‚Äôve fished, camped and went swimming there many times about forty years ago.

My sister and I played in a swamp next to our home as kids.  Never gave much thought to snakes or gators.  I guess we made too much noise and scared them.  We laugh at it now as we are now older than dirt.

They are ambush predators.  Yet, I see fools constantly tempt fate with small children and animals.  If you move to or visit Florida - please remember this.  Don't walk your dog by the shore of the lake.  If you do, you will be fishing for gators.

context: Could never quite understand communities that allow large predatory reptiles to live right next  to residential properties. There are small children, dogs, and even adults that risk death or injury from these deadly creatures. The community I live in restricts the breed and number of dog(s) I am allowed to own, but a six foot alligator 5 feet from the water's edge is just fine. I paid tens of thousands of dollars to have a small patch of water to look out on and higher taxes, just to have people tell me "watch the water, your kids and dogs could be attacked by an alligator".

You have obviously not spent much time in FL.  It is not a matter of "allowing" the gators to live there, it's literally THEIR home!  You learn to coexist.   

Not everything in life is utopian; if you want to live in paradise, you avoid the forbidden fruit!  Libs should learn that lesson......
Uh, yeah. This is sarcasm, right?

You really do not understand Florida at all.  First, you could remove gators every day, and more would come.  Second, they coexist with people very well.  I live in the most densely populated county in Florida, by a park with a small lake that has more alligators than anyone realizes.  I have seen nine foot gators completely hidden with people walking by within three feet of them and not even realizing they were there.  Alligators don't go out of there way to attack people.  They are part of our ecosystem here.  The only alligator attacks come when ignorant people do stupid things.  If you don't like gators, by property on a lake up north.  If you want live here, play by the rules.

As long as PEOPLE DO NOT FEED the gators, pester or molest them and simply either ignore them OR if they're close take actions to drive them away everything is fine. The problems arise when the gators associate people with easy food that the gators become dangerous!!! Besides Gators were on our planet LONG before humans were and have just as much right to be here as WE have if not more especially when construction encroaches on THEY'RE habitat!!!!
